entry.title: SAP Build Apps: Getting data with “Get Record Collection” or maybe “HTTP Destination Request”?
entry.content:
“Get Record Collection”

The most common (and comfortable) way to get data from backend is to use “Get Record Collection” flow function. All we need to do is to install an integration with SAP system via its REST API using SAP BTP Destination.

 

 

 

If we enable the “Autogenerate configuration” option during installation of the integration, we will get even definition of the data structure, ready to use as a template for data variables.

 

 

We can even easily add call parameters, which are to be added to the relative path as a query – all we need is to add additional inputs in the entity definition:

 

These additional inputs will be automatically added in the relative path and in the test section of the data entity. And we can use these additional inputs to send additional parameters with the API call:

 

 

And, as data variable uses in fact “Get Record Collection” flow function in the background, we also can do the same with “Get Record Collection” flow function:

 

 

When “Get Record Collection” is not enough

Sometimes we need some additional information, not only the data itself – we need access to the header of the backend response – something the “Get Record Collection” flow function can’t easily (if at all) provide. And this is the case with getting data from the SAP BTP Auditlog service I wrote about in the previous blog (SAP BTP Global Account audit logs using SAP BTP Auditlog service, SAP Build Apps and SAP Ai Core). The issue with the Auditlog service is hat it does not always send requested data in single run. If the response should contain more data, the Auditlog service will use “paging”. It will send first portion (page) only, and you will have to request next portion of the answer data, and next one, till all the data is received.

How do we know that our application should request next page of data? Auditlog service, when paging is used, adds appropriate information in the response header. If all the data is sent without paging, there is no additional information in the header. But if next page is ready for sending, the Auditlog service will add “paging” field in the response header. This “paging” field has the following structure:

Paging: “handle=<page id>”

The value of the “Paging” field looks like this:



As “Get Record Collection” flow function doesn’t give us access to the response header in any simple way, the better option to get data from the SAP BTP Auditlog service is to use the “HTTP Destination Request” flow function, which gives access to both: data and headers the easy way.

How to use this header field? The logic should go as follows:

  1. Empty the variable containing the data to be displayed
  2. Request data with the “HTTP Destination Request” flow function
  3. Add the body of the response to the variable containing the data to be displayed
  4. If the “paging” field exists in the response header: send next request for data to the Auditlog, but this time add value of the “paging” field to the request path as the last parameter and jump back to step 3
  5. If the “paging” field doesn’t exist in the response header: display the content of the variable containing data

The logic should look like this:

 

How to get access to the response header? Using a formula. We can use the “outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders” in the formula. As the header is a json, it is enough to know the names of fields in the header and then we can check if field exists in the header:

IS_UNDEFINED(outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging

This function returns “true” if the field id undefined, otherwise it returns “false”.

And then, if we know that the field exists, we can get its value simply by its name like this:

outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging

in the “Set App Variable” or “Set Page Variable” flow function.

I use both functions in single formula in the “Set Page Variable” flow function:

IF(IS_UNDEFINED(outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging), "no_paging", outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging)

If the “paging” field is not defined in the header, the formula sets “no_paging” as the variable value. But if the “paging” field is defined, the formula sets its value as the variable value.

entry.title: SAP Build Appsの「Repeat with」の使い方とポイント
entry.content:
SAP BTP Hackathon 2025が無事終了しました。ご参加いただいた皆様、ありがとうございました。毎年多くの方にご参加いただき、今年も大変盛り上がりました。
毎年参加チーム数や提出作品のレベルが上がっており、運営側としては嬉しい悲鳴でした。

 

その中で、今年はSAP Build Appsの「Repeat with」の使い方についてのご質問が多かったように思えましたので、使い方とポイントを解説したいと思います。

 

「Repeat with」機能とは？

「Repeat with」機能はUIデザイン上で同じコンポーネントを繰り返し使用するための機能です。例えば、リストやテーブルなど、同じ形式のデータを複数表示する場合に非常に便利です。
「同じコンポーネント」というのは、例えばテキストやImageなどのUI要素のことを指します。

これらのUI要素のRepreat withプロパティに「内部がオブジェクトになっているリスト型変数」をバインドすることにより、そのオブジェクトに残像のようなエフェクトが付きます。

「内部がオブジェクトになっているリスト型変数」とはSAP Build AppsのVariable上で以下のような定義の変数を指します。


変数定義としてはList型であり、その中のItemのタイプとしてObject型、そのオブジェクト型の中にTextや数値型などのプロパティを含んでいる構造です。これはJSONで記述すると以下のようなものになります。

[
  {
    "id": 1,
    "name": "Alice",
    "contact": {
      "email": "alice@example.com",
      "phone": "123-456-7890"
    }
  },
  {
    "id": 2,
    "name": "Bob",
    "contact": {
      "email": "bob@example.com",
      "phone": "098-765-4321"
    }
  }
]

実行時にRepeat withで繰り返し表示がされる回数は与えたリスト型の変数の要素数（長さ、Length）に依存します。例えば、5つの要素を持つリスト型の変数を指定すると、5回繰り返し表示されます。
 

使い方

上に挙げたJSONのデータを利用してみます。このJSONのデータ形式をSAP Build Apps上で表現すると下記のような変数になります。

JSONの値をこの変数に代入して、Repeat withで使用してみます。

Repeat withにSampleListをバインドします。このHeadLineアイテムのContent（表示内容）にnameのデータを表示したいと思います。HeadLineアイテムのContentのアイコンをクリックし


Data Items in repeatをクリックし、

Currentをクリックするとウインドウ下部に展開されます。

"current"は現在の行を意味し、その中のどれをContentにバインドするか？ということです。nameを選択します。
プレビュー実行してみます。

このように一つのHeadLineアイテムが勝手にリピートされ、バインドしたリスト型の変数の要素（行）を繰り返し、その現在行に応じたデータを表示してくれます。これがRepeat withの機能です。

更に実践

このRepeat withできる要素にはRowやContainer等複数のUI要素をまとめる機能を持ったコンポーネントも含まれます。
Rowコンポーネント中にはCellが含まれていて横に並ぶようになっています。このRowコンポーネントを縦に並べると表のようなものが出来上がりますね。Rowコンポーネントを4セル設定にして、各セルにTextコンポーネントを配置し、Rowコンポーネント自体にRepeat withで変数を設定して各セルにid,name,email,phoneのプロパティをバインドさせた例がこちらです。

Rowコンポーネントのスタイルを変更して枠線を追加すれば表になるなということがわかるかと思います。

ちなみに、ROWコンポーネントのCellに対してRepeat withで変数をバインドすると、


Listの要素数分横に並べるということも出来ます。

Listの要素数（行数）が多いので表示される行数を絞りたいという場合は変数操作が必要です。Repeat withでバインドする際にFormulaを使用して式の形でバインドすると良いでしょう。例えば

SELECT関数を使用するとリスト型変数から要素の範囲を絞ったものを抜き出すことが出来ます。

例1：　　SELECT(appVars.SampleList, index <10)
→ リストの先頭10件　（リストは0から開始します。）
例2：　　SELECT(appVars.SampleList, index >= 10 && index < 20)
→リストの11件目から20件目まで

応用すればページ表示のようなことも出来ますね。

画面の表示される範囲を制御したいという場合はRepeat withするコンポーネントをScroll Viewコンポーネントの中に配置すると良いでしょう。

そうするとScroll View側のスタイルの設定で、Scroll View内で表示されることになります。

Repeat withは必要な回数分UIコンポーネントを繰り返し表示できる便利な機能です。是非使いこなしてください。

entry.title: Empowering SAP Build Apps with SAP Translation Hub: Multilingual Support for Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
In today’s global business landscape, offering multilingual support is crucial for reaching a broader audience. SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Translation Hub, in combination with SAP Build Apps, provides a powerful, no-code solution for automating translations in web and mobile applications. This blog demonstrates how you can create a translation feature—that can be embedded in SAP Service Cloud V2 environments or used as a standalone application.

In this blog, we'll demonstrate how to:

  • Translate case data dynamically using SAP Translation Hub APIs.
  • Integrate this logic in a low-code/no-code app built with SAP Build Apps.
  • Embed the translation component directly into SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2, or run it as a standalone app.

Prerequisite

  • SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2
  • SAP BTP Global Account with appropriate entitlements
  • SAP Build Apps subscription
  • Translation Hub service activation
  • Basic understanding of SAP integration patterns

The Business Scenario

Consider a typical service management case in an SAP environment where:

  • Service teams need to handle customer issues across different geographical regions
  • Customers submit cases in their native languages
  • Technical documentation and knowledge bases exist in multiple languages
  • Cross-functional teams require real-time translation capabilities for efficient collaboration

we can see how language barriers can impact service delivery when dealing with technical descriptions, customer communications, and knowledge base content.

Key Features Illustrated

  • Source Language Selection (e.g., English)
  • Target Language Selection (e.g., German)
  • Automatic, Manual, or Batch Translation
  • User-Friendly Interface for text input and output
  • Easy embedding into other SAP solutions

Application Development

  • Create new SAP Build Apps project
  • Design translation interface components
  • Implement Translation Hub API integration
  • Configure data bindings and workflows

Solution Architecture

Our multilingual solution combines three powerful SAP technologies:

1. SAP Translation Hub

  • Real-time translation capabilities for 10+ languages
  • Context-aware translations for technical terminology
  • Integration APIs for seamless embedding

2. SAP Build Apps

  • Low-code development platform for rapid application creation
  • Responsive design capabilities for multi-device support
  • Seamless integration with SAP systems and external APIs
  • Visual development environment for citizen developers

3. SAP Service Cloud Integration

  • Native connectivity to existing SAP service management systems
  • Real-time data synchronization

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide

Environment Setup

  • Provision SAP BTP subaccount
  • Enable required services (Build Apps, Translation Hub)
  • Configure authentication and authorization

SAP Translation Hub 

you can click on View Subscription to see your application access under Instances and Subscriptions. 

In Instances and Subscriptions, click the dots to open the menu and select Create Service Binding.

In the dialog, enter a binding name, such as demo-binding as the name of your service binding. Click Create to create the service binding.

The following file formats are supported:

Type Format
HTML*.html (UTF-8 encoding)
Microsoft Office*.docx, *.xlsx, *.pptx
Text*.txt (UTF-8 encoding)
XLIFFxliff1.2
PDF*.pdf
SubRip Subtitle*.srt
WebVTT (Web Video Text Track)*.vtt
 

SAP Document Translation API supports real-time file translation via:

  • FormData (HTML-style form submission)
  • RAW
  • JSON

Endpoint:
POST /api/v1/translation

🔧Key Parameters

Parameter Type Description

fileformDataFile to translate (optional).
sourceLanguagequeryLanguage code of the original text (optional – auto-detect if omitted).
targetLanguagequeryLanguage code of the translated text (required).
strictModeboolean(Optional) Enforce structural tag consistency. Default: false.
modelstringChoose "default" (SAP MT) or "llm" (LLM-based translation). Default: default.

MIME Types Supported:

Common formats like .txt, .pdf, .docx, .html, .srt, .vtt, and more.

Sample curl request:

 

curl -X POST "$BASE_URL/api/v1/translation/?sourceLanguage=en-US&targetLanguage=de-DE" \ -H "Authorization: Bearer $XSUAA_TOKEN" \ -F 'file=@/Users/Documents/demo.txt'

Similarly we need to configure for SAP Build Apps

SAP Build Apps

This opens the SAP Build lobby.

Within the SAP Build lobby, click Create.

Click Application, and click Next.

 

 

Click Frontend, and click Next.

 
 
 
Click Web & Mobile Application, and click Next.
 

Name the new app by entering:

 

Field Value
NameTranslation Hub Application
DescriptionTranslation Hub 

Click Review.

 
On the Summary page, click Create.

 

Your SAP Build Apps project is created, and the default Home page is displayed. Once created, projects can be accessed again at any time from the SAP Build lobby.

Drag the Essentials like drop down ,container, button and input put and and adjust as per you requirement 

Invoke the Translation Hub API through a button click to fetch the case description using the Service Cloud V2 Case ID, and update the source language text accordingly

The preview looks as mentioned below for my requirement 

In SAP Build Apps, the case description is auto-populated by consuming the Service Cloud V2 API. This text can either be auto-translated or translated on demand with the click of a button using the integrated translation service.

Translation Hub

Conclusion

The combination of SAP Translation Hub and SAP Build Apps provides a powerful foundation for building multilingual enterprise applications. Whether deployed as an embedded component within existing SAP solutions or as a standalone application, this approach delivers:

  • Rapid Development: Low-code platform accelerates time-to-market
  • Enterprise Grade: Built on SAP's trusted cloud infrastructure
  • Scalable Architecture: Supports growth from pilot to global deployment
  • Cost Effective: Reduces development and operational costs
  • Future Ready: Positioned for emerging AI and ML capabilities

By breaking down language barriers in service management processes, organizations can deliver superior customer experiences, improve operational efficiency, and unlock new opportunities in global markets.

entry.title: Unlocking Multilingual Document Translation with SAP Build Apps + SAP Translation Hub
entry.content:
In our previous blog post, we explored how to enable text translation within SAP Build Apps using SAP Translation Hub, making apps more inclusive and globally accessible.

Now, let’s take this a step further. What if you need to translate entire documents—like Word files, PDFs, or HTML content? In this post, we’ll demonstrate how to integrate SAP Build Apps with SAP Translation Hub to create a document translation flow—quickly, efficiently, and without writing extensive code.

📖Story: One Quote, Two Languages — One Lost Deal?

Meet Alex, a sales manager at a global electronics company based in Germany. He’s chasing a big opportunity with a Japanese client. The quote is ready, the price is right — but it’s in English. The client requests it in Japanese.

Alex scrambles. He asks a colleague for help. He copy-pastes parts of the quote into a translation tool. He worries about accuracy, especially with technical terms. Meanwhile, the competitor — who sent a native-language quote — wins the deal

Could this have been avoided? Absolutely.

Enter SAP Build Apps + SAP Translation Hub — a powerful no-code solution to translate sales quotes and documents instantly, either as a standalone tool or tightly integrated with SAP CX Sales Cloud.

🧰 Prerequisites

To implement this solution, you’ll need:

  • ✅SAP BTP subaccount with access to:
    • SAP Build Apps
    • SAP Translation Hub (entitlement required)
  • ✅SAP CX Sales Cloud (optional, for embedded use case)
  • ✅Document format: PDF, DOCX, or HTML
  • ✅BTP Destination or integration layer (CAP / SAP Integration Suite)

🎯Use Case: Quote Translation in SAP Sales Cloud

Sales teams often generate quotes in their default language. However, sending proposals in a customer’s native language improves clarity, trust, and conversion rates.

Example:
A salesperson in Spain generates a quote in English and wants to send it to a client in Brazil. Using this solution, the salesperson uploads the quote, selects “Portuguese (Brazil)” as the target language, and receives a translated document — within seconds.

The translated document is then sent directly to the customer or attached to the Sales Cloud opportunity.

🛠️ How It Works

  1. Generate Quote (SAP CX Sales Cloud): Standard PDF/Word output from a quote process.
  2. Upload to SAP Build Apps: User uploads the file and selects target language.
  3. Translation via SAP Translation Hub: The file is translated via secure API calls.
  4. Return Translated File: File is returned as downloadable content or pushed back to SAP Sales Cloud in attachment Tab.

🔄 Deployment Options: Standalone or Integrated

Option 1: Standalone App (No SAP CX Required)

  • A universal tool for business users across sales, legal, procurement, etc.
  • Upload any business document and get instant translations.
  • Deploy via SAP Build Apps and BTP — no coding needed.
  • Useful even for companies not yet using SAP Sales Cloud.

Option 2: Embedded in SAP CX Sales Cloud

  • Add translation buttons directly in the Quote Object Page.
  • Automatically trigger translation after quote generation.
  • Store translated versions in the same quote  record.

📈 Business Benefits

Benefit Standalone App SAP Sales Cloud Integration

BenefitStandalone AppSAP Sales Cloud Integration
🌐Global content readiness✅Translate any document✅Translate sales-specific content
🕒Fast time-to-quote✅Instant translation✅Automated translation post-quote
🛠️ Low-code implementation✅Fully no-code UI✅Extendable via BTP/Events
🔐Secure enterprise workflow✅Controlled via BTP auth✅Audit-ready and version controlled
📦Reusable across teams✅Any department can use✅Tight sales workflow integration

SAP Translation Hub - Document Translation - Overview

 

 

 

Benefit Standalone App SAP Sales Cloud Integration

Step By Step

Please create the destination with the necessary values.

Drag and drop the required components onto the user interface.

Fetch and bind available languages directly from the Translation Hub API

Upload the PDF file in English format from the local file system

After selecting the target language, click the "Translate" button to proceed.

Video

Until now, we explored the process as a standalone document. Now, let’s look at how this can be embedded within the CX Sales Cloud V2 Quote :

  • 💼Seamless Integration with CX Sales Cloud V2 Quote
    Embed the translation workflow directly into the quoting process.
  • 📄Sales Representative Uploads the Quote PDF
    The sales rep can upload a quote document in their native language.
  • 🌐Automatic Translation to Desired Language
    The uploaded PDF is translated into the target language using SAP Translation Hub.
  • 📎Translated Document Attached Automatically
    The translated PDF is added to the Attachments tab of the quote.
  • ✉️Send via DocuSign for Digital Signature
    The finalized, translated quote is sent to the customer through DocuSign for e-signature.

Embed the above standardized document into the Sales Cloud V2 Quote document.

The document was originally shared via a standard email. This same method can also be utilized to initiate a DocuSign signature request

Architecture

SAP Sales Cloud 
                     ↓
SAP Build Apps UI (File Upload + Language )
                     ↓
BTP Integration (Destination)
                    ↓
SAP Translation Hub API (Document Translation)
                    ↓
Translated Quote Returned to Build App → Uploaded back to Sales Cloud or emailed

📝Conclusion

Translating sales quotes and documents no longer needs to be a manual, error-prone, or time-consuming task. With the powerful combination of SAP Build Apps and SAP Translation Hub, businesses can easily deliver personalized, localized content—whether in a standalone translation portal or as an embedded feature within SAP Sales Cloud.

This solution empowers sales teams to communicate more effectively, close deals faster, and build stronger relationships with global customers—all without writing a single line of code on the frontend.

As businesses continue to expand across borders, language accessibility becomes a strategic advantage. By embracing low-code translation automation, you're not just simplifying operations — you're enhancing the customer experience where it counts the most.

entry.title: Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
After this post was written, with the help of the wonderful community, we came up with a different, and in most ways, better solution for this issue. See https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/triggering-process-in-shared-environment-from-sap-build-apps-better/ba-p/14183502.

But what's written in this blog is still valuable, because it will show you how to use the relatively new flow function HTTP Destination Request, which lets you easily and still with a good amount of control call APIs using destinations.

Unfortunately, the Processes flow functions to trigger processes from SAP Build Apps (for now) do not work for shared environments. And since the public environment is deprecated, that means they essentially no longer work at all.  Hopefully this will be modified soon.

In the meantime, here's how to work around that issue.

The Issue

I am not sure but I assume the issue is that when you make an API call to trigger a process in a shared environment, you must send the environment id as a query parameter.

/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=salesgroup

But the flow functions do not have an input for the environment, so they automatically try to trigger a process in the public (default) environment.

By the way, the identifier for an environment can be found when you open the environment in the Control Tower.

The Workaround

The good news is SAP Build Apps recently added a new flow function called HTTP Destination Request that lets us create a customized HTTP request but using a destination. That is we get the control we get from the HTTP Request flow function but with the ability to connect through a destination.

As a prerequisite you need to have a destination called sap_process_automation_service_user_access to the SAP Build Process Automation service, the same as if you wanted to use the Processes flow functions. This is described in the Processes documentation.

You will need to add the destination properties so that it appears in your SAP Build Apps project:

BuildApps.Enabled = true
BuildApps.ApiType = rest

To add the destination to your project:

  1. Go to the Integrations tab.
  2. Click Add Integration.                                                         
  3.  Click BTP Destinations.
  4. Select the destination.
  5. Click Install Integration.                      

If you go back to the Integrations tab main screen, you'll see the destination. That's all you need to do to add the destination to the project and make it available to your HTTP Destination Request flow function.

To trigger a process deployed to a shared environment, do the following:

  1. Add a button.
  2. In the logic canvas for the button, add an HTTP Destination Request, along with any Alert flow functions to show the result or error
  3. Select the HTTP Destination Request, and set the following in the Properties tab.
    Destinationsap_process_automation_service_user_access
    HTTP MethodPOST
    Request Body Typejson
    Request BodyThis depends on the proper request body for your process. More on this below.
    Path
    /workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=<environment ID>

    Replace the placeholder with the identifier for your environment.

    Response Typetext

       

The flow function has 3 outputs.

  • The first if the call is successful and returns 2XX status code.
  • The second if the call is successfully transmitted and a response is received but returns a 4XX or 5XX status code.
  • The third if the call is unsuccessful and no response is received.  

Request Body

The request body is determined by checking the trigger for the process.

  1. Go to the Control Tower.
  2. Click Environments.
  3. Click your environment.
  4. Click Triggers.
  5. Click View next to the trigger for your process.

You will now see the payload for the API for that trigger. This will be the request body.

Note that you cannot copy from the box with the payload. You will have to use the copy button to copy the entire payload. Note also you can see the URL for the API, including the environmentId parameter you must pass.

The Upshot

The method above is pretty straight-forward and has the advantage of teaching you what is happening behind the scenes and how the SAP Build Process Automation APIs work. But I'll admit you lose the ease of use of the flow functions, and also the ability to create variables from the input and output schema of your processes.

entry.title: Extend a Custom Business Object created with Key User Extensibility using SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
This blog post covers how to setup an extension scenario from SAP S/4HANA Cloud and build Side-by-Side UI Extensions with the help of SAP Build Apps in the Business Technology Platform.

Business scenario:

A Manager wants to define business objects “Bonus Plan” for employees. A Bonus Plan is there to save employee specific rules for bonus entitlement.

Here, with Key User Extensibility, we create a custom Business Object with a data structure, logic for data initialization in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition which should have standard API operations (GET, POST, DELETE). Expose the custom business object as web service for side-by-side UI extension using Low-code No-code capabilities of SAP Build Apps. You will learn how quickly a new UI application can be developed with the no-code capabilities of SAP Build Apps. You will also find out what is the process to setup, develop and deploy a productive extension application.

Note: The maintain Bonus app shown in this blog is for educational purpose only and not meant for productive usage. It is not ensured that the data used in this extension scenario is managed in accordance with applicable legal requirements for all countries and industries and in accordance with the business needs, such as data life cycle requirements.  

Prerequisites:

  1. Subscription to SAP Build Apps on SAP BTP Sub-Account
  2. Your user needs (a) business role(s) with business catalogs Extensibility - Custom Business Objects (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_CBO), Extensibility - Custom Communication Scenarios (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_CCS) and Communication Management (ID: SAP_CORE_BC_COM) (Need to have unrestricted access if you are creating a business role and adding these catalogs).
  3. You have Created Custom Business Objects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud as per the given tutorial.                                                                

Why SAP Build Apps with SAP S/4HANA Cloud?

Create new solutions using the secure, no-code SAP Build Apps with SAP S/4HANA. Build visually and empower users to digitalise their daily work without impacting core processes. Create a personalised, accessible application that securely connects to data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

To extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud using SAP Build Apps, you can leverage side-by-side extensibility, which allows you to build extensions that run on SAP BTP and interact with your S/4HANA Cloud system. This approach enables you to create custom UIs, logic, and integrations without directly modifying the core S/4HANA Cloud system. 

 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Let’s start on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud side with the definition of the Custom Business Object and the communication settings.

Custom Business Object

In the Create Custom Business Objects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud tutorial group it is shown how to create a custom business object and generate a UI (user interface) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Expose Custom Business Object as External API

To integrate custom business object from SAP S/4HANA system with External Systems or Services like SAP Build Apps, as administrator you need to create a Communication Arrangement. You create a communication arrangement to enable the communication between your system and SAP Build App in BTP, and how they communicate. Communication Arrangement is formed by combining the below artifacts:

  1. Creating a Custom Communication Scenario
    The setup of the communication (inbound and outbound) between SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP starts with the definition of a Custom Communication Scenario.
    The Custom Communication Scenario contains the information for both inbound and outbound HTTP-calls.
    • Open the app Custom Communication Scenarios in the Launchpad of the SAP S/4 HANA system and create a new Custom Communication Scenario with the name YY1_BONUSPLAN.

     

    • On the tab Inbound Services, you create an entry for your Custom Business Object: Press Add button to add inbound service “YY1_BONUSPLAN_CDS” and click select button. 

     

    • Press Save and Publish to finish the custom communication scenario creation.

     

  2. Creating a Communication System and User

entry.title: Why Clean Core matters - Get some insights into our brand new Extensibility Whitepaper
entry.content:
What is “clean core”?

Let’s dive a bit deeper to understand what exactly this means: A SAP Cloud ERP Private has a clean core when it is up to date, documented, unmodified, consistent, efficient, and has custom extensions decoupled from SAP source code.

The clean core concept has multiple dimensions:

  • Business Processes: reduce complexity, because complex processes slow down upgrade cycles
  • Extensibility: decouple extensions from the standard
  • Data: control the data to the latest standards, with respect to volume, cleanliness, accuracy
  • Integration: keep your IT landscape reliable and flexible, using standard APIs and events
  • Operations: keep your operations effective and efficient

In this blog post, we will focus on the method for maintaining this clean core while adapting SAP solutions to meet specific business needs, which is called “clean core extensibility”. Flexibility will continue to benefit you in the future if extensions are built and utilized in adherence to clean core principles. For this, SAP provides the private cloud extensibility model for SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Note: The clean core concept only applies to SAP Cloud ERP Private, as the SAP Cloud ERP cannot be customized in its source code, only extended. For the SAP Cloud ERP, SAP provides the public cloud extensibility model for SAP Cloud ERP, which also leverages the SAP BTP.

Now, back to extending SAP Cloud ERP Private.

 

What Is New: The Evolution Of The 3-Tier Model – Introducing The Clean Core Level Concept

SAP is evolving its extensibility guidelines by introducing the Clean Core Level Concept, a new model designed to simplify qualification criteria and provide a more pragmatic approach to managing custom code in SAP Cloud ERP Private, now including rules for classic ABAP. By evolving the previous 3-tier model, this new maturity model categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D) based on their architectural integrity, upgrade safety, and alignment with clean core principles.

This allows for a more granular assessment of an extension's quality and upgrade stability, rather than a simple binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. The core recommendation remains a "BTP-first" strategy, aiming for the highest possible level, but the new model acknowledges the realities of complex, grown system landscapes and allows customers to  personalize their clean core journeys. The fundamental principles of Clean Core—decoupling extensions from the standard SAP code to ensure upgrade stability—remain essential.

 

How It Works: The Four Clean Core Levels Explained

According to the Clean Core Level Concept, each extension is evaluated using a standardized methodology that looks at how the extension is built, how well it is decoupled from the core, and how easily it can be upgraded or maintained. Here are the key details of the Clean Core Level Concept:

Overview of Clean Core Levels

The Clean Core Level Concept categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D), each representing varying degrees of compliance with Clean Core principles:

  1. Level A : Extend with SAP Build

    • Description: Extensions in this level are fully compliant with Clean Core principles and interact with SAP standard functionality through publicly released interfaces and extension points.
    • Characteristics:
      • Side-by-Side: Developed on SAP BTP, utilizing all options of the SAP Build portfolio including AI-powered pro-code and low-code tools.
      • On-Stack: Built within the SAP SAP Cloud ERP Private system using the ABAP Cloud development model with released APIs.
    • Benefits: Maximum upgrade stability and alignment with SAP's clean core vision.

  2. Level B : Leverage Classic APIs

    • Description: Extensions at this level can access "classic APIs" from SAP, in addition to meeting Level A criteria.
    • Characteristics:
      • These APIs are well-defined, documented, and generally upgrade-stable but do not come with formal stability contracts.
      • Classic technologies and frameworks can be used, which have a long-standing history of reliable use.
    • Benefits: Broader scope for process enhancements compared to Level A while maintaining a degree of upgrade stability.

  3. Level C : Access Internal Objects

    • Description: Extensions classified as Level C can access internal SAP objects that are not officially released or supported.
    • Characteristics:
      • These objects may lack documentation and long-term stability guarantees.
      • A changelog for SAP objects is provided to help customers assess upgrade risks proactively.
    • Benefits: Offers flexibility for legacy scenarios but poses notable risks regarding future upgrade stability.

  4. Level D : Not Recommended Extensions

    • Description: Extensions in this category use objects or techniques that SAP has explicitly marked as "not recommended."
    • Characteristics:
      • Includes modifications to SAP standard code, implicit enhancements, and direct write access to SAP tables.
      • Represents the highest risk and the most significant technical debt.
    • Consequences: These extensions threaten system stability and upgradeability and should be prioritized for immediate remediation.

Importance of the Level Concept

  • Granular Assessment: The level concept allows for a more nuanced evaluation of extensions compared to a binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. This granularity helps organizations understand the specific risks associated with their custom code.
  • Guidance for Development: By categorizing extensions into levels, developers can make informed decisions about which technologies and practices to adopt, aiming for the highest possible level of compliance.
  • Facilitating Modernization: The framework supports organizations in managing their existing codebases effectively, helping them prioritize remediation of the highest-risk extensions (Level D) while promoting the adoption of clean, upgrade-stable practices.

Conclusion

The Clean Core Level Concept is essential for organizations leveraging SAP Cloud ERP Private, offering a clear framework to assess and categorize custom extensions. By distinguishing between Levels A, B, C, and D, it enables businesses to make informed development decisions, prioritize remediation of high-risk extensions, and ensure compliance with Clean Core principles. This structured approach not only helps manage technical debt but also simplifies upgrades and enhances overall system integrity, paving the way for sustained agility and innovation. Embracing this framework is key to maintaining a robust and future-ready ERP landscape.

Leverage SAP Build for creating extensions

The go-to place following SAP-recommended best practices to create extensions optimized for SAP software development is SAP Build. It includes

  • powerful low-code, pro-code (ABAP, Java, JavaScript), and generative AI capabilities
  • enhanced interoperability with SAP Cloud ERP Private

to empower developers and business experts to create extensions for SAP software with greater efficiency. It allows you to accelerate ERP modernization, foster innovation, and automate processes – all within a single comprehensive suite of solutions.

 

Accelerate extension of SAP S/4HANA with AI capabilities enabled by Joule

New levels of Cloud ERP efficiency can be unlocked with the latest AI capabilities enabled by Joule in SAP Build. Joule is SAP’s AI copilot offering conversational interactions in the respective business context. Uniquely trained on SAP data and processes, it helps developers write code and design workflows for SAP S/4HANA across ABAP, Java, JavaScript, and low-code tools. As an integral part of SAP Build, Joule is the copilot for SAP development and makes developers more efficient with their development tasks for SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Joule generates high-quality code and code explanations aligned with SAP’s programming models, thereby reducing development time for both new and experienced developers and accelerating migration to cloud ERP with a clean core.

AI capabilities enabled by Joule can also be used to extend ERP through low-code application development. Joule assists with process automation, expediting the creation of workflows for SAP Cloud ERP Private and guiding workflow approvers with automated recommendations.

How to Get Started?

First and foremost, read our white paper on Clean core extensibility for SAP Cloud ERP Private . The last chapter of the document details the six-step path to a clean core and links to many useful resources to deep dive:

  1. Start with the clean core concept and definition
  2. Apply the concept and create your specific clean core strategy
  3. Analyze existing custom code (brownfield only)
  4. Adopt extension guidelines and methodologies
  5. Establish clean core governance and operations
  6. Build extensions

In addition, depending of the line of business you’re involved in, read our eBook presenting how to Extend SAP S/4HANA with SAP Build with use cases by LoB, including Finance, Supply chain, Sales and service, Operations and IT.

And regarding the use of SAP Build for extending your ERP, I recommend watching the replay of our SAP Build Live online event on Clean Core extensibility with SAP Build held on October 23, where our partner LeverX shared insights from a real customer use case.

For ABAP-based extensibility for clean core see the ABAP Extensibility Guide.

Finally, we have a learning journey for you:

Managing Clean Core for SAP Cloud ERP Private will present you how to evaluate and apply clean core principles to ERP so that they can maximize business process agility, reduce adaptation efforts, and accelerate innovation. It is for beginners, takes 2 hours and is free.

Now you're ready to begin your fruitful journey to achieve Clean Core!

entry.title: SAP BTP Hackathon at SAPHILA 2025: Celebrating the Winners and Innovation in Action
entry.content:
A few months ago, we shared our excitement about the launch of the first-ever SAP BTP Hackathon in Africa in joined collaboration of AFSUG and SAP, highlighting the unique opportunity it offered for AFSUG members to bring their creativity and problem-solving skills to the forefront of the SAP community. Now, with the event behind us, it’s time to reflect on what unfolded and celebrate the teams and ideas that made this inaugural Hackathon truly special.

From Ideation to Demo Jam: A Journey of Collaboration

As outlined in the previous blog, the hackathon was more than just a competition, it was a journey. Eighteen teams, representing a broad cross-section of AFSUG members, embarked on an eight-week sprint, supported by SAP BTP experts and coaches. The focus was on building real-world solutions using SAP BTP components like SAP Build, SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Integration Suite and ABAP Cloud amongst other SAP BTP based Services & Solutions.

After intensive enablement and development sessions, three teams emerged as finalists and were invited to present their solutions live at SAPHILA 2025’s Demo Jam. The energy in the room was palpable as each team showcased how SAP BTP could be harnessed to solve pressing business challenges.

And the Winner Is… PwC South Africa!

In a closely contested finale, the SAPHILA audience voted PwC South Africa as the overall winner for their AI-driven legal services platform “Legal Ease”. This solution stood out for its innovative use of AI to simplify legal document processing and understanding, a pain point for many businesses and consumers alike. “Legal Ease” enables users to scan and summarize complex contracts, ask questions in natural language, and receive clear, actionable insights. The platform even supports translation into local languages and integrates with knowledge bases for related services.

What impressed both the jury and the audience was not just the technical sophistication, but the clear business value: “Legal Ease” addresses real frustrations around contract transparency, billing and accessibility, with the potential to transform how legal services are delivered in Africa and beyond.

Honouring the Finalists: Debswana Diamond Company and Bell Equipment

Let’s not forget the other two finalists, who also delivered outstanding solutions:

  • Debswana Diamond Company tackled overtime management with an AI-powered assistant that streamlines scheduling, reduces costs and supports employee well-being.
  • Bell Equipment automated shipment tracking and document processing, helping to prevent stock shortages and improve logistics efficiency.

Both teams demonstrated the breadth of innovation possible with SAP BTP and set a high bar for future Hackathons.

Reflections and What’s Next

The Hackathon’s main objective was to foster deep collaboration between SAP and its customers, giving local teams a hands-on opportunity to explore and build with SAP BTP. The quality and diversity of solutions, especially the creative use of AI and automation, highlight the immense potential within the African SAP community.

Amanda Gibbs, CEO of AFSUG, summed it up perfectly:

“It is inspiring to witness what can be achieved in just eight weeks using SAP BTP;

we’ve seen incredible progress and innovation.”

Join the Conversation

Congratulations again to all teams who participated and especially to PwC South Africa for their winning solution! If you were inspired by the SAP BTP Hackathon or have thoughts on how SAP BTP can drive innovation in your organization, I’d love to hear from you in the comments.

And if you missed out this year, keep an eye out for future SAP BTP Hackathons - this is just the beginning!

entry.title: AI‑Powered Self‑Service Portal with SAP Build Apps and SAP Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
Abstract

In this demo, we showcase an intelligent self‑service portal built with SAP Build Apps, seamlessly integrated with SAP Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core. End users submit a service request by uploading an image . The image is analyzed in AI Core to detect key objects or issues; the findings are then merged into the case description so agents start with rich context. We also run sentiment analysis on the user’s text, helping auto‑prioritize and categorize the case. The result is an end‑to‑end, low‑code + AI workflow that reduces manual effort, improves accuracy, and accelerates resolution time.

Use Case: Broken Home Appliance Service Request

Scenario:
A customer’s washing machine stops working and makes unusual noise. Instead of calling customer support, they log into the self-service portal built on SAP Build Apps.

What you’ll build

A responsive self‑service portal where customers can:

  • Log in, fill a lightweight form, and upload a photo (e.g., broken product/utility issue).
  • See real‑time AI insights (objects detected; suspected issue) before submitting.
  • Submit a Service Request (Case) to Service Cloud V2, with AI context appended to the description and sentiment tag auto‑set.

Agents in Service Cloud V2 will see a richer ticket with:

  • Customer text + image URL/attachment.
  • AI object/issue summary and confidence scores.
  • Sentiment label (Positive/Neutral/Negative) for quick triage.

Solution Overview

The solution leverages three modern SAP technologies:

  • SAP Build Apps: Low-code environment for building web/mobile self-service portals.
  • SAP BTP Destination: Secure connection layer to backend SAP services.
  • SAP Service Cloud V2: Manages and tracks customer service cases.
  • SAP AI Core: Automates image analysis and sentiment analysis to enhance ticket information

The workflow (as visualized below) demonstrates how these layers interact:

  • End-to-End Ticket Automation: Instantly raise service requests by uploading an image.
  • AI-Powered Image Analysis: Automatic detection of objects or issues in uploaded images via SAP AI Core.
  • Auto-Enriched Ticket Descriptions: AI writes relevant context and details.
  • Sentiment Analysis: Analyzes customer descriptions for emotion and urgency for better case triaging.

Reference architecture

 

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have the following in place:

SAP BTP Account with access to:

  • SAP Build Apps service
  • SAP AI Core service
  • SAP Service Cloud V2 tenant

Service Keys and Destinations:

  • Properly configured SAP BTP Destination for Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core

AI Models Deployed:

  • Object Detection model ( in SAP AI Core)
  • Sentiment Analysis model
  • Basic understanding of SAP BTP, Destinations, and Service Cloud concepts

Step‑by‑step build guide

1.Prepare Your AI Services in SAP AI Core

  • Deploy or onboard your image recognition and sentiment analysis models to SAP AI Core.
  • Expose these models through RESTful endpoints.

2. Configure Destinations in SAP BTP Cockpit

Create destinations for:

  • SAP Service Cloud V2 API
  • SAP AI Core inference endpoints
  • Set appropriate authentication methods (OAuth2, Basic, etc.).

3.Build the Self-Service Portal with SAP Build Apps

  • Use SAP Build Apps’ drag-and-drop interface to design a user-friendly portal.
  • Add functionality for:
    • User authentication
    • Image upload
    • Input fields for additional ticket information
  • Configure data resources to connect to SAP Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core via the BTP destinations.

entry.title: Triggering Process in Shared Environment from SAP Build Apps - Better Solution 😸
entry.content:
In my previous blog post Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps,  I showed you how to trigger from SAP Build Apps a process that was deployed to a shared environment  -- using HTTP Destination Request instead of Processes flow functions.

Though I thought it was pretty easy -- and I liked it because I could control the API call and see what was going on under the hood -- it still required me to know the APIs as well as to give up on some of the cool SAP Build Apps capabilities that come with the Processes flow functions (like automatic generation of schemas from inputs/outputs of a process).

Thanks to @KuroKen, I discovered a better way, who commented on my original post.

At first I struggled to get the solution to work, even though I was assured it worked. But as usual, the struggling was good and revealed all kinds of additional nuances about the system (see Issues below). After 2 weeks of study, here's my explanation of this solution.

The Problem (reminder)

SAP Build Apps has a wonderful set of flow functions that makes it easy to trigger processes (and run other SAP Build Process Automation APIs). 

But the problem is that they were developed before SAP Build environments was a big thing, and certainly before the Public environment was deprecated. The API to trigger a process in a shared environment requires a query parameter specifying the environment, but the flow functions do not include this parameter and therefore the flow function can only trigger Public processes, which as we said are deprecated.

🙀

The Solution

Well, it is pretty simple -- don't require the query parameter.

But how?

When creating the SAP Build Process Automation instance in the SAP BTP cockpit, you can add a small configuration  that will assign that instance to a specific shared environment so you will not have to pass the environment name when you call the API.

To set up SAP Build Process Automation, you need to create an instance of the service. In the cockpit click Create.

You select SAP Build Process Automation, and select the standard instance plan. 

Instead of clicking Create, click Next so you can add a configuration to specify a shared environment to connect to this instance. In the dialog, you enter an environment ID and an API key with rights to trigger processes and more.

The following is the dialog where you post your configuration:

The following is an example of the JSON to set (you need to replace with your own environment ID and API key):

{
    "environmentId": "salesgroup",
    "apiKey": "fPdjgABCD-wZUckjh-c6e2wFyU3SgL"
}

 If you already have an instance, you can run Update and then supply the JSON.

Some of this process is described here: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/update-service-instance

Environment ID

The environment ID can be found when you go to Control Tower and open your environment, under Identifier.

API Key

Within the environment, you can go to the API Keys tab and create a new API key.

For the key you must give it enough scope for triggering processes, specifically the environment_read, trigger_read and trigger_execute scopes.

 

How You Trigger Process from SAP Build Apps

Now that we have overcome the problem with shared environments, here's a quick review of how to trigger a process from SAP Build Apps.

  1. Publish your deployed process project.
  2.  In SAP Build Apps, go to Integrations > Add Integration > Library, and select the process you want to expose from within the deployed project (which should appear since the project was published). Click Enable Process. 
  3. In the logic canvas (perhaps in response to a button), drag in a Processes > Trigger Process flow function. 
  4. In the flow function, specify the process to trigger and the inputs for the process.

 

Issues

The main issue was that I was using a destination with OAuth2JWTBearer (user authentication). The above works currently only for OAuth2ClientCredentials. So when @KuroKen explained his solution, I didn't understand because it didn't work for me, and he must of thought I was incompetent or crazy.

I contacted development and they confirmed that I was not crazy, that in fact there was a bug -- the client credentials and user token authentication flows used different flows and the one for user tokens had a bug. My understanding is that that bug was fixed and is awaiting deployment. As always,, no guarantees

Potential pitfall

This solution works like a charm, and restores all the great capabilities of SAP Build Apps flow functions. And as long as long as there are only a few environments, it should work pretty well.

But let's say I have 3 environments, and I create 3 instances of SAP Build Process Automation, each will require its own destination to define the connection from SAP Build Apps. But SAP Build Apps assumes the name of the destination is sap_process_automation_service_user_access. So in a  case where I want to trigger processes in different environments from my app, I think I would have a problem -- though I do not know how common a use case that would be.

I am told that there is no cost or performance issue for creating multiple instances, so that is good.

I assume that I can override the configuration by sending the query parameter for another environment, but I have not tested this.

Hope this helps,

😸

entry.title: SAP Databricks: Create inferences for application integration with SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
Part 1 – SQL analytics with SAP Data Products
Part 2 – Build and deploy Mosaic AI and Agent Tools
Part 3 – How to use AutoML to forecast sales data
Part 4 – Connect SAP Data Products with non-SAP data from AWS S3
Part 5 – End-to-end integration: SAP Databricks, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud
Part 6 – Create inferences for application integration with SAP Build 
Part 7 – SAP Databricks in SAP Business Data Cloud - A Typical Machine Learning Workflow

 

Create inferences for application integration with SAP Build Apps

In the earlier parts of the series, we explored the capabilities of SAP Databricks - from running SQL analytics and leveraging AutoML, to building end-to-end data integration with SAC. Now, we're taking things a step further.

In this post, the focus shifts from model development to real-world application - specifically, how to extend trained and deployed ML models into interactive, user-facing applications.

We’ll walk through how to:

  • Leverage data products from Unity Catalog and enhance them using notebooks
  • Serve a trained ML model for real-time inference
  • Use SAP Build Apps (low-code/no-code) to rapidly build a front-end interface that interacts with the model for inference

By integrating SAP Databricks with SAP Build Apps, we extend the powerful capabilities of notebooks into the creation of intelligent applications, enabling machine learning experiences to directly benefit end users. With SAP Build Apps, it's quick and easy to prototype and bring these ML-powered experiences to life, even without deep frontend development expertise.

 

1. Data Preparation and Feature Engineering

The goal is to train a machine learning model to predict sales order lead times based on inputs such as product, order date, and quantity. In my environment, I accessed the sales order data products from the SAP Databricks Unity Catalog, which was delta-shared from S/4 HANA.

The data was cleaned and preprocessed by addressing missing or inconsistent values, particularly focusing on improving the accuracy of the delivery dates. Relevant features were also added to enhance the dataset, including order lead time, day of the week, and month.

 

Once the data is cleaned up, I saved this back into the Unity Catalog as a delta table. Saving the cleaned and feature engineered table allows you to manage and share datasets across your teams with access control. By storing the processed table here, I could easily access it for model training, and downstream tasks while maintaining version control and consistency.

 

2. Model Training

I used XGBoost to train a model to predict the lead time based on the features. You can use any ML models that suits your use case or take a look at how to run AutoML experiments in Part 3 (link).

 

3. Mosaic AI Model Serving

Mosaic AI Model Serving offers a unified platform to deploy, manage, and run AI/ML models for both real-time and batch predictions. Once deployed, each model is exposed as a REST API that can be easily integrated into web or client applications.

The model being deployed here is a Custom Model, built using Python and trained with standard machine learning libraries or custom code. It is packaged in the MLflow format and can be registered in the SAP Databricks workspace model registry as a Python pyfunc model.

Package your model into a Python class that can be called easily:

# Model wrapper class for XGBoost regression to predict LeadTime
import mlflow.pyfunc
import pandas as pd
from mlflow.models.signature import ModelSignature
from mlflow.types import Schema, ColSpec


class LeadTimeModel(mlflow.pyfunc.PythonModel):
    def __init__(self, model_pipeline):
        self.model_pipeline = model_pipeline

    def predict(self, context, model_input):
        # Convert input to pandas DataFrame regardless of input type
        if isinstance(model_input, pd.DataFrame):
            input_df = model_input
        elif isinstance(model_input, dict):
            input_df = pd.DataFrame([model_input])
        else:
            input_df = pd.DataFrame(model_input)
        predictions = self.model_pipeline.predict(input_df)
        return pd.DataFrame({'predicted_lead_time': predictions})

# Define input and output schema
input_feature_names = [
    "SalesOrderDayOfWeek",
    "SalesOrderDay",
    "SalesOrderMonth",
    "SalesOrderItemText",
    "OrderQuantity"
]
input_schema = Schema([
    ColSpec("string", "SalesOrderDayOfWeek"),
    ColSpec("long", "SalesOrderDay"),
    ColSpec("long", "SalesOrderMonth"),
    ColSpec("string", "SalesOrderItemText"),
    ColSpec("long", "OrderQuantity")
])
output_schema = Schema([ColSpec("long", "predicted_lead_time")])
signature = ModelSignature(inputs=input_schema, outputs=output_schema)

input_example = pd.DataFrame([{
    "SalesOrderDayOfWeek": "Monday",
    "SalesOrderDay": 13,
    "SalesOrderMonth": 8,
    "SalesOrderItemText": "Y120 Bike",
    "OrderQuantity": 5
}])

with mlflow.start_run():
    mlflow.pyfunc.log_model(
        "lead-time-pred", 
        python_model=LeadTimeModel(model_pipeline), 
        input_example=input_example, 
        signature=signature, 
        registered_model_name="lead-time-prediction"
    )

With model serving, users can instantly run inferences on the trained ML models. For example, given a sales order with fields like product and quantity, the model can predict lead time on the spot. This capability allows product and operations teams to call the service live within their workflows. You can easily test the functionality first through a simple query endpoint from the model serving endpoint.

4. Accelerate Development Using SAP Build Apps

SAP Build Apps enables quick app development with a low-code platform, allowing you to create custom applications. In this section, we'll demonstrate how we can rapidly prototype a user interface to interact with the deployed model.

For testing purpose, I used the PAT (Personal Access Token).

Conclusion

The application design may vary depending on its complexity and the steps required to make it production-ready. To manage connections and handle additional logic, a backend would be needed. However, this demonstrates how to enhance a data product, serving the ML model on SAP Databricks for inference and connecting it to SAP Build Apps via API, providing a foundation to extend and build your own intelligent applications.

entry.title: “Business Excellence with SAP’s New Clean Core Extensibility Levels: Why, What and How”
entry.content:
1. Introduction:

SAP provides pre-delivered content to run your business. A Clean Core approach means keeping Cloud ERP systems up-to-date, free from unnecessary customizations, and aligned with industry best practices. This gives the benefits of driving innovation-readiness, ensuring seamless future upgrades and reducing technical debt.

1.1 Key guiding principles of a Clean Core

There are five essential guiding principles that contribute to an efficient and sustainable Cloud ERP system:

  1. Processes – Streamlining end-to-end (E2E) business workflows for efficiency.
  2. Integration – Ensuring seamless communication between extensions and core enterprise solutions.
  3. Extensibility – Extending standard software functionality to meet unique organizational needs.
  4. Data – Managing configuration, master, and transactional data effectively.
  5. Operations – Managing infrastructure, upgrades, system monitoring, and maintenance.

In this article, we will focus on the “Extensibility” guiding principle.

To support business differentiation while maintaining a Clean Core, organizations can adopt various extensibility models.  A clean core strategy doesn't mean to exclude extensibility entirely, the crucial part is understanding the appropriate way to implement the extensions.  You can create extensions using SAP Build via “Side-by-side” extensibility (loosely coupled) on BTP (including AI-enhanced pro-code and low-code tools) or through “S/4 HANA On-stack” extensibility (tightly coupled).

2. WHY New Clean Core Extensibility Levels:

SAP has refined its clean core model, evolving from the former three-tier structure to a more detailed four-level concept (A, B, C, and D). Instead of a simple “clean vs. not clean” classification. These levels show how closely your custom extensions align with clean core principles.

This evolution provides greater clarity for extension decisions and simplifies qualification criteria, giving organizations a more practical way to balance innovation with long-term sustainability. It’s about making smarter, future-proof extensibility choices while ensuring business differentiation doesn’t come at the cost of technical debt.

Here’s what it means in practice:

  1. Smarter, future-proof choices – Enable meaningful business differentiation without slowing down with legacy overhead.
  2. Clean, scalable extensions – Build on SAP BTP, ABAP Cloud, and SAP Build—all supported by Joule, SAP’s AI copilot.
  3. Progress you can measure – Monitor and track clean core adoption with tools like the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard and ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC). The dashboards will be updated and reflect the new levels.

3. WHAT are the new clean core extensibility Levels:

Before exploring the new clean core extensibility levels are, it is important to understand what an API is—because most of these levels are closely tied to APIs.

  • An API (Application Programming Interface) is essentially a defined set of rules, protocols, and interfaces that allows one software application to communicate with another.
  • In simple terms, an API acts like a bridge. It lets developers access specific functions, data, or services of a system without needing to dive into, or modify, the underlying code.

There are four extensibility levels from the cleanest form of extensions to not clean extensions.

Level A – The cleanest form of custom extensions. These are built either directly on-stack with the ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side on SAP BTP using SAP Build, whether through ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low-code/no-code tools. Represents highest standard in SAP extensibility, offering future-ready solutions with maximum upgrade stability by utilizing released API’s and extension points.

Level B –Extensions that follow SAP’s best practices for classic ABAP development and use only officially provided SAP APIs and frameworks. These extensions can be used only if the requirements cannot be fulfilled by set of released APIs (Level A). These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Level C – Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAP’s formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

Level D – Classified as not clean core. This level includes extensions that don’t follow SAP’s guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Below table explains the differences in each level for comparison.

For detailed guidance on frameworks, technologies and development patterns in the context of clean core extensibility, please refer to SAP Note: 3578329.

4. HOW to find SAP extensibility objects classification by levels:

The “SAP Business Accelerator Hub” and “Cloudification Repository (API Viewer)” are the central tools to classify objects by clean core level. It shows which objects are:

  • Released APIs (Level A)
  • Classic APIs (Level B)
  • No APIs (Level D)
  • Internal Objects (Level C – default when not classified as A, B and D)

The SAP API Business Hub is SAP’s central catalog of APIs, integration content, and business services. All the APIs are classified as Level A. Remote APIs are for consumption in BTP and local APIs are for consumption in “On-stack extensibility”.

The Cloudification Repository Viewer is an interactive tool designed to help developers explore API details for “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public” and “SAP S/4HANA Private Edition” for on-stack extensions.

Links:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (Doesn’t include Classic APIs)
  • SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API’s)

In this article, I will be demonstrating the usage of “S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition”.

4.1 Extension Level A

The cleanest form of custom extensions. These are built either directly on-stack with the ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side on SAP BTP using SAP Build, whether through ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low-code/no-code tools. You can find the released API’s at SAP Business Accelerator Hub. If you are a developer, you can find the released API’s directly in the IDE (Integrated Development Environment).

 Alternatively, for “SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition" you can follow the below steps.

Detailed Steps:

1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud ERP Private  (Doesn’t include Classic APIs)
2. Click “Show Filter Bar”

3. Choose “Released” under State drop down.

4. You have different options to filter results based on “Object type”, “Software Component” and “Application Component”

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for “purchase_order”)

4.2 Extension Level B – Classics APIs:

Extensions that follow SAP’s best practices for classic ABAP development and use only officially provided SAP APIs and frameworks. These extensions can be used only if the requirements cannot be fulfilled by set of released APIs (Level A). These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Detailed Steps on finding the Classic API’s:

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API’s)
  2. Click “Show Filter Bar”

3. Choose “Classic API” in the state 

4. You can choose filter criteria as needed

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for “sales”)

4.3 Extension Level C – Conditionally Clean

Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAP’s formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

  • You can find objects in Level A (Released APIs), Level B (Classical APIs) and Level D (No APIs).

Level C refers to all internal SAP objects that are neither “Released APIs,” “Classical APIs,” nor “APIs” at all. Since they are internal objects, no official list exists.

4.4 Extension Level D – Not Clean Core

Extensions at level D are classified as not clean core. These includes extensions that doesn’t follow SAP’s guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Detailed Steps on finding objects which are “Not APIs” classified as “No APIs”

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API’s)
  2. Click “Show Filter Bar

3. Choose “No API” in State

4. Results with “No APIs” are displayed

5. Successor information is available for some of the objects.

5. Summary:
With this evolved model, SAP is giving organizations a smarter playbook for extension decisions. By aligning with clean core principles on a clear scale (Levels A, B, C and D), businesses can innovate faster, keep their systems future-ready, and reduce technical debt—while still getting the flexibility they need today.

entry.title: Deep Dive and Experience Sharing into SAP Joule for Developers(J4D)
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog is not written by any LLM.

Well, to start with, Joule for Developers, let us understand what it is?

Many people have a misconception that Joule for Developers or J4D is just an ABAP AI capability. But it is much more beyond ABAP. Joule for Developers(J4D) is collective name for the AI-powered design-time capabilities across SAP Build and ABAP

It includes new and existing features enabled by Joule in:

  1. SAP Build Code
  2. SAP Build Apps
  3. SAP Build Process Automation
  4. ABAP in SAP BTP and S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

These capabilities help developers build faster, code smarter, and automate better. Is that true? I will my honest opinion for some of them.

I have personally worked on SAP Build Apps, SAP Build Code and Joule for Developers, ABAP AI. I started with a lot of ambiguity and finally I made a mark that I could now explain it to our customers and users.

SAP Build Apps allow for generating pages to handle data entities and generate sample data automatically. It means, whenever you integrate any oData service/REST API/SAP BTP Destination, you get an option to automatically create the User Interface and also generate sample data.

SAP Build Code, has evolved through multiple iterations and seems it is still evolving. 

  • Created Fiori element app using Image
  • Created a series of projects with prompts
  • Created test data

With ABAP AI, I could create a report with the suggestions popping up in run time and that too contextually aware code prompts also known to be predictive code completion feature. We called it Ghost Code. But trust me sometimes they are really good too. 

I see the ABAP and CDS unit scripts getting generated in no time. It was good again on this parameter. 

Code explain, well I created small projects, hence feel it is good to have comments. But the true colors will be visible when you look at the repository of thousands lines of code written by someone and you have no clue of what it is. Using your skills you debug the code to understand what each block/function is doing. It is a life saver in this scenario.

SAP Build Code has the GenAI embedded as part of the service itself. There is no explicit step which need to perform other than just subscribing to this service via the Boosters (from the SAP BTP Global Account).

For SAP Build Apps and SAP Build Process Automation, everything under the new SAP Build Offering, will have the GenAI capability turned off by default. Then, how do you turn it on?

  1. Go to your SAP BTP Subaccount and access the SAP Build Apps and SAP Build Process Automation service from the 'Instances and Subscription' option
  2. SAP Build Lobby will openStep 1 - Access SAP Build Lobby

  3. Now go to the 'Control Tower' in the right hand side panel, last option and then click on the 'Generative AI' tile in the top row, right hand side 'Tenant Configuration'Step 2 - Click on Control Tower Option in Left Hand Pane

  4. Switch on the toggle button of Generative AI
    Step 3 - Click on Generative AI tile in the right hand pane

  5. Read the AI Terms and Conditions and scroll to the bottom of the Terms and Conditions to enable the checkbox of 'I have read the terms and conditions' - this is called as 'Scroll wrap agreement' in the language of Law - it means you agree to the Terms and Conditions and read till the last of the agreement.

    Step 5 - Read/Scroll to the end of the AI Terms & Conditions

  6. Click on the checkbox of 'I have read the terms and conditions'  

    Step 6 - Click on 'Accept' button on the right hand bottom corner

  7. Now click on the 'Accept' button 

    Step 4 - Turn on the toggle of Enable Generative AI features

  8. That's it. Now you can explore the GenAI capability inside SAP Build Apps and SAP Build Process Automation.

Some people have questions whether they need to sign a 0 USD AI Terms and Conditions contract to activate the GenAI capability for J4D. The answer is, except for 'Joule for Developers ABAP AI' capability, you do NOT need to sign an explicit contract for AI Terms and Conditions. They are all embedded within the services.

Well this will be an evolving document, where I will keep updating my reviews on each of these services mentioned. Stay tuned!

entry.title: SAP Build FAQ: Commercials, Getting Started and More
entry.content:
This FAQ provides an overview of SAP’s commercial offering of SAP Build. It covers the available commercial models for SAP Build and provides answers to questions that we most often hear regarding SAP Build commercial model, onboarding, metering and more. 

What is the SAP Build Unified Offering?  

SAP Build has been designed as the optimal way to extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud and other business applications. Thousands of customers are already experiencing up to 3x faster development speeds with SAP Build according to recent analyst research — and now we’ve made it even better. 

Combined with deep technical integration, SAP Builds unified offering empowers customers to quickly extend and personalize their business solutions using AI-powered application development and automation, while maintaining a clean core and eliminating additional licensing or budgeting complexity. 

What is included in the Unified SAP Build Offering?  

 Customers can access the full range of SAP Build capabilities through just four distinct SKUs.  

  • SAP Build Base User is for end users who need to access applications, gain insights for day-to-day business needs, and approve tasks. 
  • SAP Build Premium User includes all the features of the base user license, with added capabilities for end users to author content, monitor processes, customize pages and deploy attended bots. 
  • SAP Build Developer includes all the features of the Premium User license, plus advanced capabilities for developers and architects who need full access to deployed assets. 
  • SAP Build Runtime Application hosting and lifecycle management services that support the creation and execution for dev/test as well as production environments 

How do I find out what is included in SAP Build?  

  • For a list of services that are included in SAP Build you can visit the SAP Discovery Center, for SAP Build following this link 
  • To find out what is in each SKU, Base, Premium, Developer and Runtime you can visit the SAP Build Pricing Page here. 

What commercial models are SAP Build provided in?  

Consumption Based Model:  

  • SAP BTP Enterprise Agreement (BTPEA) 
  • SAP Cloud Enterprise Agreement (CPEA) 
  • Pay-As-You-Go for SAP BTP 

Subscription Based Commercial Mode:  

  • Service Plan for SAP Build Subscription 

SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition:  

  • SAP Build Entitlements are included in the SAP Cloud ERP Edition 
  • Find more about SAP Cloud ERP Edition here   
  • Find out more about the SAP Build offering in SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition here 

SAP Business Suite Packages: 

  • Entitlements are provided in several of the SAP Business Suite packages 

Partner: 

  • SAP Build offers partners free access to SAP Build and other BTP Services. 
  • SAP Build Test, Demo Development (the site requires you to be logged in as an SAP Partner) 
     

How do I get started with SAP Build?  

SAP Build uses SAP BTPs Cloud Integration Automation (CIA) to quickly get customers and partners up and going on SAP Build.  Find information on how to setup SAP Build here.  For detailed instructions on the activation process, please share this blog post with your technical team 

Does SAP Build include Joule Studio and Joule for Developer?   

Yes, SAP Build provides Joule for Developer and Joule Studio.  Joule Studio is provided with the SAP Build Developer offering.  Joule for Developer features are included, but will need to enable this through the free voucher SKUs.  You can find more information on Joule for Developer here and Joule Studio here. 

Are there specific service plans that are exclusive to the unified SAP Build offering? 

The Joule Studio service is only offered in the SAP Build Developer SKU. Joule for Developer needs to be enabled through the free voucher SKU's and then can only be used with the SAP Build offering, SAP Build Code and Joule for Developer, BTP ABAP Environment.  Visual Cloud Functions in SAP Build Apps is not available in the SAP Build unified SKU. 

Can I migrate from the previous SAP Build SKU’s to the new SAP Build SKU?  
 
Upgrade you SAP Build licenses to access enhanced features and tools.  Use build-specific plans for improved efficiently and customization in your projects.   

For migration of services please refer to this help 

 Can I use both the Old and New Service plans within the same subaccount? 

 The old services cannot be enabled in the same subaccount as the new Build services.  You will need to do a migration per the above migration guide. 

 How does metering work, for example if I use both SAP Build Base User and SAP Build Developer capabilities? 

SAP Build operates on a metering model that relies on specific user roles to determine access and functionality within the platform, which include developer, base user, and premium user. Each user must have a global user ID created by an administrator, who also assigns the appropriate role collection to ensure that the correct authorization is granted. 

This role assignment is critical; for instance, an SAP Build base user shouldn't be able to create new processes within SAP Build, as such permissions could lead to unintended alterations or disruptions in workflows. By understanding and correctly implementing these roles, organizations can effectively manage user capabilities while maintaining the integrity and security of their SAP Build environment. 

For more detailed information on metering and roles visit this help location. 

 How can I learn more about SAP Build?  

  •  SAP Build Basic Trial–Get hands-on experience with a free, 30-day trial, following a step-by-step tutorial on SAP Build. 
  • SAP Discovery Center–Dive deeper with step-by-step guidance and best practices for implementing use cases.  
  • SAP Learning –Develop SAP skills for free, anywhere, anytime, and at your own pace: SAP Build

はじめに 

　本ブログは「SAP BTP Hackathon 2025」において、一次選考を通過し、ファイナリストとなったアクセンチュア株式会社様(以下、アクセンチュア)、デロイト トーマツ コンサルティング合同会社様(以下、デロイト トーマツ)、株式会社JSOL様(以下、JSOL)の3社によって行われた座談会についての記事です。
　「SAP BTP Hackathon2025」は、SAPジャパン株式会社が主催するパートナー/ユーザー企業を対象としたハッカソンイベントで、与えられた課題に対して、SAP Business Technology Platform ( ※1) (以下、BTP)を用い短期間で集中的に開発を行いその成果を競い合うイベントです。 今回の課題は、「SAP業務にAIでサプライズを！それ、A​​Iに任せません？」です。4年目の開催となった今年のハッカソンは、38社47チーム354名が参加されました。
　2025年5月よりEnablementセッションを実施し、同年6月に1週間のハッカソン（バーチャル形式）を行いました。 数多くの応募作品の中からSAPジャパンで一次選考を行い、ファイナリスト6組を選出。7月9日（水）にSAPジャパン本社オフィスにて開催された発表イベントで最終選考を実施しました。
　ファイナリストに選ばれた6社様を2組に分け、座談会という形で各チームの作品や、BTPの各機能についてお話を伺いました。
